mdRecord.dcterms:description: On land and with money inherited from her grandfather, Mary and Charles Sprague commissioned Herbert Browne to design a hilltop house .... Browne completed a white-clap-boarded Colonial Revival house with formal entrance court, which the Spragues occupied in 1896. In 1896 Charles A. Platt, a young New York artist who had recently completed a country house and garden for Sprague's doctor in Needham, was hired to design the grounds. The Platt plan included a broad grass terrace supported by a high retaining wall west of the house, a geometric flower garden with curving end pergola to the south, a woodland garden on the hillside above the house to the east, and a service court to the north. The clear geometry of the plan attracted many imitators. Charles Sprague won election to Congress in 1896 but died in 1902. To make the house more appropriate for the Italian spirit of the garden, his widow invited Herbert Browne to encase the frame dwelling in brick, adding another story and a large ballroom and conservatory. -- http://sah-archipedia.org/ [work]
